This is a report I wrote for B6.3 Integer Programming as part of my MSc in MMSC. It's on the binary cutting stock problem, a one-dimensional integer programming problem. I used an algorithm called branch-and-price, and implemented it (quite hurriedly) in Python.

It is written in typst and compiled using their very incomplete HTML function, so there are quite a few rendering issues, but it should be mostly comprehensible. The report is here, and the code is here.

I use Neovim btw, and this is a blog post about it.

TLDR: use vim motions, and here's my config

I think everyone should learn vim motions. For the amount of time it takes to learn (maybe a week if you're a full-time dev?), it will save you so much time and frustration. Even if you're still an Eclipse fan in 2025, I'd highly recommend learning the basics of vim motions.

Also, here's my Neovim config.

Read on if you're really interested in my very generic opinions on Neovim.

Neovim vs vim

I use Neovim over vim because I prefer lua over vimscript, and there are a lot of Neovim-only plugins. Unless you're really into some weird niche thing vim has kept since 1976, I'd recommend you also use Neovim.

Why not VSCode?

The main reason I use Neovim over VSCode is (surprise surprise) the customizability. Its entire design philosophy is built around the idea that every part of the editor should be modifiable and extensible. Neovim in particular uses lua as its scripting language, which means if you're able to code something in lua, you can get it to run in your editor.

Also, Neovim (can) very nicely follow the Unix philosophy. As a very picky person, I much prefer being able to pick separate tools. For example, VSCode all but forces you to use their terminal, but Neovim has great interoperability with tmux.

If you know you're not into messing with config files for ages or optimizing your keybinds, then I probably wouldn't recommend Neovim. However, if you're even a little bit curious, I'd really recommend giving it a shot. Here are some resources I used to get started:

It's a very basic and quite buggy Pong clone on the 3DS. I learned a lot about C++ and it motivated me to work on better projects.

In August 2025, I started seriously aiming for quantitative finance roles, and so decided to create what is probably the most common quant dev project.

This is a price-time priority matching engine written in C++. I implemented basic functionality for Good-Till-Cancel limit orders. Unit testing is done with Google test.

The design of this order book is largely influenced by this article from 2011, especially the use of ordered maps for storing limits, and a lock-free ring buffer for updating external observers.

It's quite a small project, but it took me a good amount of effort due to my relative lack of experience with C++ at the time. This is the project which best represents my C++ skills.

Potential future to-dos:

  • Add more order types (Fill-Or-Kill, Market Orders, Stop Orders)
  • Create a more thorough API for getting order data.
  • Test its performance much more thoroughly using realistic sample data and better profiling tools.

This is my dissertation for my BSc in Mathematics at the University of St Andrews, titled Time-splitting spectral methods for the Schrödinger equation in the semi-classical regime.

I looked at a specific class of numerical integrators for the Schrödinger equation, proved some convergence/stability results, and confirmed these results computationally.

Click on the link in the title to see the entire project, or click here for some very out-of-context graphs.

I enjoyed this project so much that it convinced me to go through with a master's. Shout out to my supervisor Irene Kyza for pushing me to create something I'm proud of.

This project, which then became a publication in Physical Review Fluids titled Dynamically relevant recurrent flows obtained via a nonlinear recurrence function from two-dimensional turbulence, was my first bit of research experience, and currently my only publication.

This resulted from the StARIS internship at the University of St Andrews. My only contributions are the majority of Section IV, where I used k-means clustering, pruning, and regression techniques to predict certain quantities of a turbulent flow.

Click here for some pretty pictures generated by my co-authors, or here for some (not as pretty) plots that I created.

This was my first foray into computational maths research, and I am extremely thankful to my supervisor Dan Lucas for all of his support and mentorship. I would not be where I am now without his help.
